oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Educational Leadership the Black Woman Way: A Collaborative Autoethnography of Black Women Educational Leaders in P-20 Contexts
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Juergensen, Miyoshi
Thomas, Tamela
Croft, Sheryl
Elue, Chinasa
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Black women educational leaders
intersectionality
bridge leadership
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The article explores our experiences of Black women who have held leadership positions across the Pre-K to graduate education spectrum. It delves into our respective leadership realities and styles, which are significantly influenced by the intersectionality of race, gender, spirituality, and time. The study employs a collaborative autoethnographic approach to provide an in-depth analysis of our personal and collective leadership experiences and highlights the complexities of leading as a Black woman in educational environments. Findings mostly confirm the existing literature on Black women school leaders, while adding that the common themes and experiences are evident irrespective of the educational contexts where Black women are leading.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Journal of African American Women and Girls in Education; Vol. 5 No. 2 (2025): Winter 2025; 144-174
